sos.title: Distress Message Generator
sos.description: Use this guide to construct a clear and standardized distress message in case of an emergency.

alert.title: Real Emergencies Only!
alert.description: This procedure should only be used in situations of grave and imminent danger. Stay calm and speak clearly.

step1.title: MAYDAY, MAYDAY, MAYDAY
step1.description: Repeat three times to ensure attention is caught and it's distinguished from other communications.

step2.title: This is [Vessel Name]...
step2.description: Clearly identify your vessel, repeating the name three times.

step3.title: Call sign and MMSI
step3.description: Provide your call sign and/or MMSI number for unique identification.

step4.title: MAYDAY (again)
step4.description: Repeat MAYDAY once more to begin the body of the message.

step5.title: Position
step5.description: State your position as accurately as possible (GPS, lat/long, or reference to a known point).

step6.title: Nature of distress
step6.description: Briefly describe the emergency (e.g., 'we are on fire', 'we are sinking', 'collision').

step7.title: Assistance required
step7.description: State what kind of help you need (e.g., 'I require immediate assistance', 'I require evacuation').

step8.title: Persons on board
step8.description: Report the number of people on the vessel.

step9.title: Other information
step9.description: Any other relevant information (e.g., 'vessel is blue', 'we have a life raft', 'we have injured people').

step10.title: OVER
step10.description: Indicates you have finished your transmission and are awaiting a response.

lights.sidelights_making_way: Sidelights and sternlight if making way.
lights.nuc_lights: Two all-round red lights in a vertical line.
lights.pdv_lights_making_way: And also, masthead, side, and sternlights if making way.
lights.sidelights_stern_making_way: And also, sidelights and sternlight if making way.
lights.ram_lights: Three all-round lights (red, white, red) in a vertical line.
lights.cbd_lights: Three all-round red lights in a vertical line.
lights.aground_lights: Two all-round red lights in a vertical line.

marks.cone_sailing_motor: Cone, apex down (if also using propulsion).
marks.nuc_marks: Two balls in a vertical line.
marks.ram_marks: Ball, diamond, and ball in a vertical line.
marks.trawl_mark: Two cones with their apexes together.
marks.aground_marks: Three balls in a vertical line.

R23.title: Power-driven Vessel Underway
R23.description: Standard lights for a power-driven vessel.
R23.explanation: Masthead lights indicate presence and, to some extent, vessel length. Sidelights (red/green) and sternlight (white) define its orientation and direction.

R24.title: Towing and Pushing Vessels
R24.description: Lights and marks for vessels engaged in towing operations.

towing_lt200.title: Towing, tow < 200m
towing_lt200.description: A vessel towing another, with a tow length of less than 200 meters.
towing_lt200.explanation: Two masthead lights indicate towing. The yellow towing light above the sternlight is key to identifying it from the stern.

towing_gt200.title: Towing, tow > 200m
towing_gt200.description: A vessel towing another, with a tow length exceeding 200 meters.
towing_gt200.explanation: Three masthead lights indicate a long tow (>200m), which requires more caution. By day, the diamond shape is mandatory.

pushing.title: Pushing Ahead
pushing.description: A vessel or group of vessels pushing rigidly ahead.
pushing.explanation: When pushing, they are considered a single power-driven vessel, thus they exhibit the normal lights of Rule 23.

R25.title: Sailing Vessel Underway
R25.description: Lights for a vessel under sail.
R25.explanation: Sailing vessels show sidelights and a sternlight. They may optionally show two all-round lights (red over green) at the masthead, but not in conjunction with the combined lantern.

R26.title: Fishing Vessels
R26.description: Lights and marks for vessels engaged in fishing.

trawling.title: Trawling
trawling.description: Vessels engaged in fishing with trawls or other gear that restricts maneuverability.
trawling.explanation: Green over white indicates trawling. These lights give it preference over most other vessels.

fishing_not_trawling.title: Fishing (other than trawling)
fishing_not_trawling.description: Vessels fishing, but not trawling (e.g., longline, purse seine).
fishing_not_trawling.explanation: Red over white indicates another type of fishing. It also has right-of-way. If the gear extends more than 150m, it must show a white light in that direction.

R27.title: Vessels Not Under Command or Restricted in Ability to Maneuver
R27.description: Lights for vessels that cannot maneuver or have limited ability to do so.

nuc.title: Not Under Command (NUC)
nuc.description: A vessel which through some exceptional circumstance is unable to maneuver.
nuc.explanation: Two all-round red lights in a vertical line are the universal signal for 'not under command.' This vessel cannot get out of the way, and others must avoid it.

ram.title: Restricted in Ability to Maneuver (RAM)
ram.description: A vessel which from the nature of her work is restricted in her ability to maneuver.
ram.explanation: Red-White-Red indicates the vessel is performing work (dredging, underwater ops, etc.) and cannot easily move. If making way, it also shows the lights of a normal vessel.

R28.title: Vessels Constrained by their Draught (CBD)
R28.description: Lights for vessels which, because of their draught, are severely restricted in their course.
R28.explanation: The three vertical red lights (or a cylinder by day) do not grant right-of-way under the rules but serve as a clear warning to other vessels to avoid impeding its passage.

R29.title: Pilot Vessels
R29.description: Lights for a vessel on pilotage duty.
R29.explanation: White over red identifies a pilot vessel on duty. When not on duty, it shows the lights corresponding to its type (usually, a power-driven vessel).

R30.title: Anchored and Aground Vessels
R30.description: Lights and marks for vessels that are not underway.

anchored.title: Anchored
anchored.description: A vessel at anchor, not aground or made fast to the shore.
anchored.explanation: One or two all-round white anchor lights (depending on length) and the ball shape by day indicate the vessel is anchored. It is a fixed position that others must avoid.

aground.title: Aground
aground.explanation: A vessel aground shows anchor lights and, additionally, two vertical red lights (or three balls by day) to indicate it is in a dangerous situation and an obstruction to navigation.

maneuver_stbd.title: Altering course to Starboard
maneuver_stbd.description: Power-driven vessel maneuvering when in sight of another.

maneuver_port.title: Altering course to Port
maneuver_port.description: Power-driven vessel maneuvering when in sight of another.

maneuver_astern.title: Operating Astern Propulsion
maneuver_astern.description: Power-driven vessel with engines in reverse.

overtake_stbd.title: Intend to Overtake on Starboard
overtake_stbd.description: Signal from a vessel intending to overtake another on its starboard side.

overtake_port.title: Intend to Overtake on Port
overtake_port.description: Signal from a vessel intending to overtake another on its port side.

overtake_agree.title: Agreement to be Overtaken
overtake_agree.description: Response from the vessel to be overtaken, if in agreement.

warning_doubt.title: Doubt / Warning Signal
warning_doubt.description: If the intentions of the other vessel are not understood, or to give a warning.

warning_bend.title: Warning at a Bend
warning_bend.description: Vessel approaching a bend or curve with obscured visibility.

restricted_vis_power_making_way.title: PDV, making way (Restricted Vis.)
restricted_vis_power_making_way.description: In restricted visibility, a power-driven vessel making way.

restricted_vis_power_stopped.title: PDV, stopped (Restricted Vis.)
restricted_vis_power_stopped.description: In restricted visibility, a power-driven vessel stopped and not making way.

restricted_vis_special.title: NUC, RAM, Sailing, etc. (Restricted Vis.)
restricted_vis_special.description: Special vessels (NUC, RAM, fishing, etc.) in restricted visibility.
restricted_vis_special.signal: ▬ ● ● (One long, two short blasts at intervals <= 2 min)

restricted_vis_towed.title: Towed Vessel (Restricted Vis.)
restricted_vis_towed.description: The last vessel of a tow, if manned, in restricted visibility.
restricted_vis_towed.signal: ▬ ● ● ● (One long, three short blasts at intervals <= 2 min)

restricted_vis_anchored_lt100.title: Anchored <100m (Restricted Vis.)
restricted_vis_anchored_lt100.description: Anchored vessel less than 100m in length.
restricted_vis_anchored_lt100.signal: Rapid bell ringing for 5s every minute.

restricted_vis_anchored_gt100.title: Anchored >=100m (Restricted Vis.)
restricted_vis_anchored_gt100.description: Anchored vessel 100m or more in length.
restricted_vis_anchored_gt100.signal: Bell at bow + Gong at stern every minute.

restricted_vis_aground.title: Aground (Restricted Vis.)
restricted_vis_aground.description: Aground vessel, in addition to anchor signals.
restricted_vis_aground.signal: Three bell strokes, ringing, three strokes.

pilot.title: Pilot Vessel
pilot.description: A pilot vessel on duty may sound this identity signal.

purposes.port_a: Indicates the port side of a channel when returning from sea.
purposes.starboard_a: Indicates the starboard side of a channel when returning from sea.
purposes.port_b: Indicates the port side of a channel when returning from sea.
purposes.starboard_b: Indicates the starboard side of a channel when returning from sea.
purposes.north: Indicates that safe water lies to the North.
purposes.south: Indicates that safe water lies to the South.
purposes.east: Indicates that safe water lies to the East.
purposes.west: Indicates that safe water lies to the West.
purposes.isolated_danger: Erected on a danger of limited extent.
purposes.safe_water: Indicates navigable water all around the mark.
purposes.special_mark: Indicates a special area or feature (cable, pipeline, etc.).

mnemonics.port_a: When returning, green to starboard, red to port.
mnemonics.starboard_a: When returning, green to starboard, red to port.
mnemonics.port_b: 'Red Right Returning' - When returning to port, keep red buoys to starboard.
mnemonics.starboard_b: 'Red Right Returning' - When returning to port, keep red buoys to starboard.
mnemonics.north: Two cones pointing up (North). Continuous quick white flashing light.
mnemonics.south: Two cones pointing down (South). 6 flashes + 1 long flash.
mnemonics.east: Cones with bases together (like an Easter egg). 3 flashes every 5s.
mnemonics.west: Cones with apexes together (like a wine glass). 9 flashes every 10s.
mnemonics.isolated_danger: Two black spheres, two white flashes.
mnemonics.safe_water: Spherical with vertical stripes. White isophase, occulting, or long-flashing light.
mnemonics.special_mark: Yellow with an 'X' topmark. Yellow light.

page.title: International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea (COLREGs)
page.description: An interactive study guide on the rules of the road.

rule1.title: Rule 1: Application
rule1.point1: Apply to all vessels in the high seas and connected waters.
rule1.point2: Do not interfere with special rules for roadsteads, harbours, rivers, etc.
rule1.point3: Local special rules should conform as closely as possible to the international Rules.
rule1.point4: The Organization may adopt traffic separation schemes.
rule1.point5: A vessel of special construction or purpose may be exempted if she cannot fully comply without interfering with her function.

rule2.title: Rule 2: Responsibility
rule2.point1: Nothing in these Rules shall exonerate any vessel from the consequences of any neglect.
rule2.point2: Due regard shall be had to all dangers of navigation and collision.
rule2.point3: Departure from the Rules may be necessary to avoid immediate danger.

rule3.title: Rule 3: General Definitions
rule3.subpoint1: Vessel: includes every description of water craft.
rule3.subpoint2: Power-driven vessel: any vessel propelled by machinery.
rule3.subpoint3: Sailing vessel: any vessel under sail, provided that propelling machinery is not being used.
rule3.subpoint4: Vessel engaged in fishing: any vessel fishing with nets, lines, trawls or other fishing apparatus which restrict manoeuvrability.
rule3.subpoint5: Vessel not under command (NUC): a vessel which through some exceptional circumstance is unable to manoeuvre.
rule3.subpoint6: Vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre (RAM): a vessel which from the nature of her work is restricted in her ability to manoeuvre.
rule3.subpoint7: Vessel constrained by her draught (CBD): a power-driven vessel which because of her draught is severely restricted in her course.
rule3.subpoint8: Underway: not at anchor, or made fast to the shore, or aground.

partB.title: Part B - Steering and Sailing Rules

section1.title: Section I - Conduct of vessels in any condition of visibility

rule5.title: Rule 5: Look-out
rule5.point1: Every vessel shall at all times maintain a proper look-out by sight and hearing.
rule5.point2: Use all available means appropriate in the prevailing circumstances.
rule5.point3: This includes radar, VHF, and other equipment.

rule6.title: Rule 6: Safe Speed
rule6.point1: Every vessel shall at all times proceed at a safe speed so that she can take proper and effective action.
rule6.point2: Factors to be taken into account: visibility, traffic density, manoeuvrability, background lights, wind, sea, current, and draught.

rule7.title: Rule 7: Risk of Collision
rule7.point1: Every vessel shall use all available means to determine if risk of collision exists.
rule7.point2: If there is any doubt such risk shall be deemed to exist.
rule7.point3: Assumptions shall not be made on the basis of scanty information, especially scanty radar information.

rule8.title: Rule 8: Action to Avoid Collision
rule8.point1: Any action shall be positive, made in ample time and with due regard to good seamanship.
rule8.point2: Any alteration of course and/or speed shall be large enough to be readily apparent.
rule8.point3: Action taken to avoid collision shall result in passing at a safe distance.
rule8.point4: The effectiveness of the action shall be checked until the other vessel is finally past and clear.

rule9.title: Rule 9: Narrow Channels
rule9.point1: A vessel shall proceed as near to the outer limit of the channel which lies on her starboard side as is safe.
rule9.point2: A vessel of less than 20m or a sailing vessel shall not impede the passage of a vessel which can safely navigate only within a narrow channel.
rule9.point3: A vessel engaged in fishing shall not impede the passage.
rule9.point4: A vessel shall not cross a narrow channel if it impedes the passage.

rule10.title: Rule 10: Traffic Separation Schemes
rule10.point1: A vessel shall proceed in the appropriate traffic lane in the general direction of traffic flow.
rule10.point2: So far as practicable keep clear of a traffic separation line or separation zone.
rule10.point3: A vessel shall, so far as practicable, join or leave a traffic lane at the termination of the lane.
rule10.point4--: A vessel shall avoid crossing traffic lanes but if obliged to do so shall cross on a heading as nearly as practicable at right angles.

section2.title: Section II - Conduct of vessels in sight of one another

rule12.title: Rule 12: Sailing Vessels
rule12.point1: When two sailing vessels have the wind on different sides, the vessel which has the wind on the port side shall keep out of the way.
rule12.point2: When both have the wind on the same side, the vessel which is to windward shall keep out of the way of the vessel which is to leeward.
rule12.point3: If a vessel with the wind on the port side sees a vessel to windward and cannot determine the other's tack, she shall keep out of the way.

rule13.title: Rule 13: Overtaking
rule13.point1: Any vessel overtaking any other shall keep out of the way of the vessel being overtaken.
rule13.point2: A vessel shall be deemed to be overtaking when coming up with another vessel from a direction more than 22.5 degrees abaft her beam.

rule14.title: Rule 14: Head-on Situation
rule14.point1: When two power-driven vessels are meeting on reciprocal or nearly reciprocal courses, each shall alter her course to starboard.

rule15.title: Rule 15: Crossing Situation
rule15.point1: When two power-driven vessels are crossing, the vessel which has the other on her own starboard side shall keep out of the way.

rule16.title: Rule 16: Action by Give-way Vessel
rule16.point1: Every vessel which is directed to keep out of the way of another vessel shall, so far as possible, take early and substantial action.

rule17.title: Rule 17: Action by Stand-on Vessel
rule17.point1: The stand-on vessel shall keep her course and speed. She may take action if the give-way vessel is not taking appropriate action.

rule18.title: Rule 18: Responsibilities Between Vessels
rule18.point1: Hierarchy (from most to least maneuverable): Power-driven > Sailing > Fishing > Not under command or restricted in ability to maneuver.

section3.title: Section III - Conduct of vessels in restricted visibility

rule19.title: Rule 19: Conduct in Restricted Visibility
rule19.point1: Proceed at a safe speed adapted to the prevailing circumstances.
rule19.point2: If a vessel is detected by radar alone, determine if a risk of collision exists and take avoiding action in ample time.

rule20.title: Rule 20: Application
rule20.point1: Rules concerning lights shall be complied with from sunset to sunrise.

rule21-31.title: Rules 21-31
rule21-31.point1: These rules define the characteristics and placement of lights (masthead, sidelights, sternlight, etc.) and shapes for each type of vessel and situation, as shown in the simulator.

partD.title: Part D - Sound and Light Signals

rule32-37.title: Rules 32-37
rule32-37.point1: Define the equipment for sound signals and the signals for maneuvering and warning (short/long blasts), as well as distress signals.

partEF.title: Parts E & F - Exemptions and Verification

rule38.title: Rule 38: Exemptions
rule38.point1: Allows for exemptions for vessels built before the rules came into force.

rule39-41.title: Rules 39-41: Verification of Compliance
rule39-41.point1: Deal with the implementation and enforcement of the regulations.

clouds.title: Cloud Types
clouds.description: Visual guide to identify the main cloud genera and their meaning.

cirrus.name: Cirrus (Ci)
cirrus.description: Fibrous, white, and delicate clouds with a silky appearance. They often indicate the approach of a warm front and a change in weather.

cirrocumulus.name: Cirrocumulus (Cc)
cirrocumulus.description: Thin, white cloud layers composed of small elements in the form of grains or ripples. Known as a 'mackerel sky'.

cirrostratus.name: Cirrostratus (Cs)
cirrostratus.description: Transparent, whitish cloud veil that covers all or part of the sky. They often produce halo phenomena around the sun or moon.

altocumulus.name: Altocumulus (Ac)
altocumulus.description: White or grey cloud layer, with its own shading. They have the appearance of slabs, rolls, or pebbles.

altostratus.name: Altostratus (As)
altostratus.description: Greyish or bluish cloud sheet, of striated or uniform appearance, covering the sky. The sun or moon may be visible as if through ground glass.

nimbostratus.name: Nimbostratus (Ns)
nimbostratus.description: A grey, dark cloud layer, often with a veiled appearance, with continuous precipitation of rain or snow that reaches the ground.

stratus.name: Stratus (St)
stratus.description: A grey, uniform cloud layer, similar to fog but not touching the ground. It can produce drizzle, ice prisms, or snow grains.

stratocumulus.name: Stratocumulus (Sc)
stratocumulus.description: A layer of grey or whitish clouds with dark parts, composed of rounded masses or rolls. They do not usually produce precipitation.

cumulus.name: Cumulus (Cu)
cumulus.description: Detached, dense clouds with sharp outlines. Their base is horizontal and their upper part is dome-shaped. They indicate fair weather if they do not develop vertically.

cumulonimbus.name: Cumulonimbus (Cb)
cumulonimbus.description: Massive and dense clouds with great vertical development, in the form of a mountain or tower. Associated with thunderstorms, showers, hail, and electrical activity.
